situations.text:
The Parliament of the United Kingdom is the supreme legislative body of the United Kingdom, and the British overseas territories. It alone possesses legislative supremacy and thereby ultimate power over all other political bodies in the UK and the overseas territories. Parliament is bicameral but has three parts, consisting of the sovereign (Crown-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons (the primary chamber). The two houses meet in the Palace of Westminster in the City of Westminster, one of the inner boroughs of the capital city, London.
The House of Lords includes two different types of members: the Lords Spiritual, consisting of the most senior bishops of the Church of England; and the Lords Temporal, consisting mainly of life peers, appointed by the sovereign, and of 92 hereditary peers, sitting either by virtue of holding a royal office, or by being elected by their fellow hereditary peers. Prior to the opening of the Supreme Court in October 2009, the House of Lords also performed a judicial role through the Law Lords.
The House of Commons is an elected chamber with elections to 650 single member constituencies held at least every five years under the first-past-the-post system. The two houses meet in separate chambers in the Palace of Westminster. By constitutional convention, all government ministers, including the prime minister, are members of the House of Commons or, less commonly, the House of Lords and are thereby accountable to the respective branches of the legislature. Most cabinet ministers are from the Commons, whilst junior ministers can be from either house.
The Parliament of Great Britain was formed in 1707 following the ratification of the Treaty of Union by Acts of Union passed by the Parliament of England and the Parliament of Scotland, both Acts of Union stating, 'That the United Kingdom of Great Britain be represented by one and the same Parliament to be styled The Parliament of Great Britain.' At the start of the 19th century, Parliament was further enlarged by Acts of Union ratified by the Parliament of Great Britain and the Parliament of Ireland that abolished the latter and added 100 Irish MPs and 32 Lords to the former to create the Parliament of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. The Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927 formally amended the name to the 'Parliament of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland', five years after the secession of the Irish Free State.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom

questions.text: According to the passage, the Queen does not have legislative supremacy over the UK Parliament
questions.explanation: In the 1st paragraph, the passage states that the UK Parliament “alone possesses legislative supremacy” – therefore no one else can have legislative supremacy, including the Queen. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: All government ministers must be a member of either the House of Commons or Lords
questions.explanation: In the 3rd paragraph the passage states that “by constitutional convention, all government ministers… are members of the House of Commons or… the House of Lords”. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: There are 750 total members of the House of Commons
questions.explanation: In the 2nd paragraph, it states that the House of Commons has elections for 650 single member constituencies – therefore only 650 members are elected. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: The secession of the Irish Free State could have occurred in 1922
questions.explanation: In the last paragraph, it states that Parliamentary Titles Act of 1927 was amended 5 years after the Irish Free State secession – therefore 5 years before 1927 is 1922 – so it is possible the secession occurred in 1922. Therefore, the answer is A.

The O. J. Simpson murder case was a criminal trial held in Los Angeles County Superior Court. Former National Football League (NFL) player, broadcaster, and actor O. J. Simpson was tried on two counts of murder for the June 12, 1994 slashing deaths of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ron Goldman. At 12:10 a.m. on June 13, 1994, Brown and Goldman were found stabbed to death outside her condominium in the Brentwood neighbourhood of Los Angeles. Simpson became a person of interest after police found a bloody glove behind his house and was formally charged with the murders on the morning of June 17. When he did not turn himself in at the agreed time (having previously been released after perfunctory questioning by police detectives), he became the object of a low-speed pursuit in a white 1993 Ford Bronco SUV owned and driven by his friend Al Cowlings. TV stations interrupted coverage of the NBA finals to broadcast the incident. The pursuit was watched live by an estimated 95 million people. The pursuit, arrest, and trial were among the most widely publicized events in American history. The trial—often characterized as the trial of the century because of its international publicity—spanned eleven months, from the jury's swearing-in on November 9, 1994. Opening statements were made on January 24, 1995, and the verdict was announced on October 3, 1995, when Simpson was acquitted on two counts of murder. According to USA Today, the case has been described as the 'most publicized' criminal trial in history.
Simpson was represented by a high-profile defense team, also referred to as the 'Dream Team', which was initially led by Robert Shapiro and subsequently directed by Johnnie Cochran. The team also included F. Lee Bailey, Alan Dershowitz, Robert Kardashian, Shawn Holley, Carl E. Douglas, and Gerald Uelmen. Barry Scheck and Peter Neufeld were two additional attorneys who specialized in DNA evidence.
Deputy District Attorneys Marcia Clark, William Hodgman and later Christopher Darden thought that they had a strong case against Simpson, but Cochran was able to convince the jury that there was reasonable doubt concerning the validity of the State's DNA evidence, which was a relatively new form of evidence in trials at that time. The reasonable doubt theory included evidence that the blood sample had allegedly been mishandled by lab scientists and technicians, and there were questionable circumstances that surrounded other court exhibits. Cochran and the defense team also alleged other misconduct by the LAPD related to systemic racism and the actions of Detective Mark Fuhrman. Simpson's celebrity status, racial issues, and the lengthy televised trial riveted national attention.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O._J._Simpson_murder_case

questions.text: It 4 days for OJ Simpson to be charged with the murders from when the bodies were discovered
questions.explanation: In the 1st paragraph, it states that the bodies were discovered on the morning of June 13, and OJ was charged on the morning of June 17 – which is 4 days. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: The trial was classified as the ‘trial of the century’ due to the fact that it was the most publicised criminal trial in history
questions.explanation: The characterisation of the trial as the ‘trial of the century’ – is due to “its international publicity” – however we cannot say that the fact that it was the ‘most publicised’ case in criminal history has nothing to do with this characterisation. The passage provides a reason for the characterisation, however provides no evidence that the fact that it was the ‘most publicised’ case in criminal history was NOT a cause. We do not know if the reason they gave for the characterisation was the ONLY reason. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: The mishandling of the blood sample by lab scientists can be attributed to the relatively new nature of DNA evidence
questions.explanation: This is an assumption and nothing in the passage mentions a causal relationship (cause-effect) between the mishandling of the blood sample and the new nature of DNA evidence. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: OJ Simpson was wrongfully arrested due to systemic racism in the LAPD
questions.explanation: Although the defense team for OJ alleged this, there is no definitive statement in the passage that backs this statement up (they could allege anything but there is nothing in the passage that proves this). Therefore, the answer is C.

Matchlock firearms were used in India by 1500, in Đại Việt by 1516, and in Southeast Asia by 1540. According to a Burmese source from the late 15th century, King Meng Khoum II would not dare attack the besieged town of Prome due to the defenders' use of cannon and small arms that were described as muskets, although these were probably early matchlock arquebuses or wall guns.
The Portuguese may have introduced muskets to Sri Lanka during their conquest of the coastline and low lands in 1505, as they regularly used short barreled matchlocks during combat. However, P.E.P.Deraniyagala points out that the Sinhalese term for gun, 'bondikula', matches the Arabic term for gun, 'bunduk'. Also, certain technical aspects of the early Sinhalese matchlock were similar to the matchlocks used in the Middle East, thus forming the generally accepted theory that the musket was not entirely new to the island by the time the Portuguese came. In any case, soon native Sri Lankan kingdoms, most notably the kingdom of Sitawaka and the Kandyan Kingdom, manufactured hundreds of Sinhalese muskets, with a unique bifurcated stock, longer barrel and smaller calibre, which made it more efficient in directing and using the energy of the gunpowder. These were mastered by native soldiers to the point where, according to the Portuguese chronicler, Queirós, they could 'fire at night to put out a match' and 'by day at 60 paces would sever a knife with four or five bullets' and 'send as many on the same spot in the target.'
Arquebuses were imported by the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644) at an uncertain point, but the Ming only began fielding matchlocks in 1548. The Chinese used the term 'bird-gun' to refer to arquebuses and Turkish arquebuses may have reached China before Portuguese ones. In Zhao Shizhen's book of 1598 AD, the Shenqipu, there were illustrations of Ottoman Turkish musketmen with detailed illustrations of their muskets, alongside European musketeers with detailed illustrations of their muskets. There was also illustration and description of how the Chinese had adopted the Ottoman kneeling position in firing while using European-made muskets, though Zhao Shizhen described the Turkish muskets as being superior to the European muskets. The Wu Pei Chih (1621) later described Turkish muskets that used a rack-and-pinion mechanism, which was not known to have been used in any European or Chinese firearms at the time
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musket

questions.text: The musket is a type of matchlock firearm
questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph implies that muskets are a form of matchlocks – as the “Portuguese may have introduced muskets to Sri Lanka… as they regularly used short barrelled matchlocks”. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.explanation: It is implied in the 2nd paragraph that the muskets must have been accurate if the native soldiers were able to “put out a match” with them. Even though the soldiers were skilled enough to do so, if the guns were inaccurate then they wouldn’t be able to do so regardless. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.explanation: There is nothing to suggest a comparison between Turkish and Sri Lankan muskets. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.explanation: Even though this feature is not mentioned in the passage, that does not mean the gun did not have this mechanism as the passage does not state that the muskets ONLY had “bifurcated stock(s), longer barrel(s) and smaller calibre(s)”.

A pearl is a hard, glistening object produced within the soft tissue (specifically the mantle) of a living shelled mollusk or another animal, such as fossil conulariids. Just like the shell of a mollusk, a pearl is composed of calcium carbonate (in a pearl, mainly aragonite or a mixture of aragonite and calcite) in minute crystalline form, which has been deposited in concentric layers. The ideal pearl is perfectly round and smooth, but many other shapes, known as baroque pearls, can occur. The finest quality of natural pearls have been highly valued as gemstones and objects of beauty for many centuries. Because of this, pearl has become a metaphor for something rare, fine, admirable and valuable.
The most valuable pearls occur spontaneously in the wild, but are extremely rare. These wild pearls are referred to as natural pearls. Cultured or farmed pearls from pearl oysters and freshwater mussels make up the majority of those currently sold. Imitation pearls are also widely sold in inexpensive jewellery, but the quality of their iridescence is usually very poor and is easily distinguished from that of genuine pearls. Pearls have been harvested and cultivated primarily for use in jewellery, but in the past were also used to adorn clothing. They have also been crushed and used in cosmetics, medicines and paint formulations.
Whether wild or cultured, gem-quality pearls are almost always nacreous and iridescent, like the interior of the shell that produces them. However, almost all species of shelled mollusks are capable of producing pearls (technically 'calcareous concretions') of lesser shine or less spherical shape. Although these may also be legitimately referred to as 'pearls' by gemological labs and also under U.S. Federal Trade Commission rules, and are formed in the same way, most of them have no value except as curiosities.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl

questions.text: The shell of a mollusc is composed of aragonite and/or calcite
questions.explanation: The aragonite and calcite mixture composition is stated to be “in a pearl”, however we do not know if the calcium carbonate in the shell of a mollusk shares this. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: A baroque pearl is not round and smooth
questions.explanation: In the 1st paragraph, it states that “the ideal pearl is perfectly round and smooth, but many other shapes, known as baroque pearls, can occur”. Therefore baroque pearls cannot be round 9as it is a different shape). Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: Natural pearls are worth more than cultured pearls
questions.explanation: In the 2nd paragraph, it states that “the most valuable pearls occur… in the wild” and that “these wild pearls are… ‘natural pearls’”. Therefore, all other pearls are less valuable and worth less. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: All species of shelled mollusks can create pearls of lower shine than its interior
questions.explanation: In the 3rd paragraph it states that “almost all species of shelled mollusks are capable of producing pearls of lesser shine or less spherical shape [to the interior of the shell that produces them]”. Therefore at least 1 species cannot do so (due to the word ‘almost’). Therefore, the answer is B.

A genetically modified organism (GMO) is any organism whose genetic material has been altered using genetic engineering techniques. The exact definition of a genetically modified organism and what constitutes genetic engineering varies, with the most common being an organism altered in a way that 'does not occur naturally by mating and/or natural recombination'. A wide variety of organisms have been genetically modified (GM), from animals to plants and microorganisms. Genes have been transferred within the same species, across species (creating transgenic organisms) and even across kingdoms. New genes can be introduced, or endogenous genes can be enhanced, altered or knocked out.
Creating a genetically modified organism is a multi-step process. Genetic engineers must isolate the gene they wish to insert into the host organism and combine it with other genetic elements, including a promoter and terminator region and often a selectable marker. A number of techniques are available for inserting the isolated gene into the host genome. Recent advancements using genome editing techniques, notably CRISPR, have made the production of GMO's much simpler. Herbert Boyer and Stanley Cohen made the first genetically modified organism in 1973, a bacteria resistant to the antibiotic kanamycin. The first genetically modified animal, a mouse, was created in 1974 by Rudolf Jaenisch, and the first plant was produced in 1983. In 1994 the Flavr Savr tomato was released, the first commercialized genetically modified food. The first genetically modified animal to be commercialized was the GloFish (2003) and the first genetically modified animal to be approved for food use was the AquAdvantage salmon in 2015.
Bacteria are the easiest organisms to engineer and have been used for research, food production, industrial protein purification (including drugs), agriculture, and art. There is potential to use them for environmental, purposes or as medicine. Fungi have been engineered with much the same goals. Viruses play an important role as vectors for inserting genetic information into other organisms. This use is especially relevant to human gene therapy. There are proposals to remove the virulent genes from viruses to create vaccines. Plants have been engineered for scientific research, to create new colours in plants, deliver vaccines and to create enhanced crops. Genetically modified crops are publicly the most controversial GMOs. The majority are engineered for herbicide tolerance or insect resistance. Golden rice has been engineered with three genes that increase its nutritional value. Other prospects for GM crops are as bioreactors for the production of biopharmaceuticals, biofuels or medicines.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetically_modified_organism

questions.text: It is widely accepted that the definition of a GMO is one that does not occur naturally by mating and/or natural recombination
questions.explanation: This definition is “the most common” however there is nothing in the passage indicating that it is widely accepted, however as the passage states that the definition “varies”, we can infer that even the most common definition is not widely accepted (1st paragraph). Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.explanation: Boyer and Cohen made the first GMO in 1973, however CRISPR was created “recent[ly]” (2nd paragraph, “recent advancements”) – as the most recent date in the passage is 2015, we know CRISPR was created around if not after 2015 (but at least not in 1973). Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: The first genetically modified food was the Flavr Savr tomato
questions.explanation: We do not know if the Flavr Savr was the FIRST genetically modified food, as the passage provides no indication if it was first or not, only that was released in 1994. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: Genetically modified crops are privately not the most controversial GMOs
questions.explanation: Although we know that “Genetically-modified crops are publicly the most controversial GMOs”, there is nothing to say that they are also the most controversial GMOs privately. It could be both – but we have no information about that so therefore the answer is C.

Down syndrome or Down's syndrome, also known as trisomy 21, is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of all or part of a third copy of chromosome 21. It is usually associated with physical growth delays, mild to moderate intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. The average IQ of a young adult with Down syndrome is 50, equivalent to the mental ability of an 8- or 9-year-old child, but this can vary widely.
The parents of the affected individual are usually genetically normal. The probability increases from less than 0.1% in 20-year-old mothers to 3% in those of age 45. The extra chromosome is believed to occur by chance, with no known behavioural activity or environmental factor that changes the probability. Down syndrome can be identified during pregnancy by prenatal screening followed by diagnostic testing or after birth by direct observation and genetic testing. Since the introduction of screening, pregnancies with the diagnosis are often terminated. Regular screening for health problems common in Down syndrome is recommended throughout the person's life.
There is no cure for Down syndrome. Education and proper care have been shown to improve quality of life. Some children with Down syndrome are educated in typical school classes, while others require more specialized education. Some individuals with Down syndrome graduate from high school, and a few attend post-secondary education. In adulthood, about 20% in the United States do paid work in some capacity, with many requiring a sheltered work environment. Support in financial and legal matters is often needed. Life expectancy is around 50 to 60 years in the developed world with proper health care.
Down syndrome is the most common chromosome abnormality in humans. It occurs in about 1 in 1,000 babies born each year. In 2015, Down syndrome was present in 5.4 million individuals globally and resulted in 27,000 deaths, down from 43,000 deaths in 1990.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Down_syndrome

questions.text: A young adult with Down syndrome could have an IQ of 120
questions.explanation: The passage states that the IQ of a young adult with Down syndrome can “vary widely” from 50, therefore it is possible that it could be 120. Therefore the answer is A.

questions.text: Getting pregnant at age 50 increasing the likelihood of an extra chromosome occurring
questions.explanation: The passage indicates that the probability of having a child with Down syndrome increases from a 20-year-old mother to someone who is 45 years old, however we do not know if this trend continues to 50 years, as there is nothing else to suggest the age is a factor. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: 80% of people with Down syndrome in the US required a sheltered work environment
questions.explanation: There is no statistic for the number of people with Down syndrome in the US who require a sheltered work environment, and the stat about 20% of people with Down syndrome in the US doing paid work is unrelated to this. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: In the undeveloped world, the life expectancy of someone with Down Syndrome is likely to be less than 50 years
questions.explanation: Although we know the life expectancy of those with Down syndrome in the developed world, we have no information about the undeveloped world. This question invites assumptions. Therefore, the answer is C.

The Spanish flu pandemic of 1918, the deadliest in history, infected an estimated 500 million people worldwide—about one-third of the planet’s population—and killed an estimated 20 million to 50 million victims, including some 675,000 Americans. The 1918 flu was first observed in Europe, the United States and parts of Asia before swiftly spreading around the world. At the time, there were no effective drugs or vaccines to treat this killer flu strain. Citizens were ordered to wear masks, schools, theatres and businesses were shuttered and bodies piled up in makeshift morgues before the virus ended its deadly global march.
The first wave of the 1918 pandemic occurred in the spring and was generally mild. The sick, who experienced such typical flu symptoms as chills, fever and fatigue, usually recovered after several days, and the number of reported deaths was low. However, a second, highly contagious wave of influenza appeared with a vengeance in the fall of that same year. Victims died within hours or days of developing symptoms, their skin turning blue and their lungs filling with fluid that caused them to suffocate. In just one year, 1918, the average life expectancy in America plummeted by a dozen years.
One unusual aspect of the 1918 flu was that it struck down many previously healthy, young people—a group normally resistant to this type of infectious illness—including a number of World War I servicemen. In fact, more U.S. soldiers died from the 1918 flu than were killed in battle during the war. Forty percent of the U.S. Navy was hit with the flu, while 36 percent of the Army became ill, and troops moving around the world in crowded ships and trains helped to spread the killer virus.
Although the death toll attributed to the Spanish flu is often estimated at 20 million to 50 million victims worldwide, other estimates run as high as 100 million victims—around 3 percent of the world’s population. The exact numbers are impossible to know due to a lack of medical record-keeping in many places. What is known, however, is that few locations were immune to the 1918 flu—in America, victims ranged from residents of major cities to those of remote Alaskan communities.
Source: https://www.history.com/topics/world-war-i/1918-flu-pandemic

4% of the US Navy did not show symptoms of the flu

questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph states that “the average life expectancy in America plummeted by a dozen years” in 1918. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: With regards to the victims impacted by the Spanish flu, all of the following are true except
options: US special forces were unusually struck down by the flu

During the autumn 1918, the absence of a vaccine meant people would die of suffocation
questions.explanation: There is nothing to say that people who developed symptoms during the second wave would ultimately die – only that victims died quickly within developing symptoms (but nothing to suggest that death was inevitable). Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: According to the passage, all of the following are false except:
options: Alaskan communities were immune to the flu
Healthy, young people generally immune to illness were safe from the flu
The flu did not result in mortality in 2019
97% of the world’s population may have stayed alive during the flu
questions.explanation: If 500 million people is equal to a third of the global population, the population would be about 1.5 billion (1st paragraph). Therefore, if a maximum estimate of 50 million people died, that would equate to 3% of the population dying. Therefore is possible that 97% of the population did not die from the pandemic, so the answer is D.

Solo is an Australian lemon-flavoured soft drink currently manufactured under license by Asahi Beverages. Launched in 1968 - first in a bottle, then in a 375ml can, by Tarax drinks. It is a ready to drink version of traditional 'pub squash'. There are various versions of Solo available, including Solo Zero, which uses artificial sweetener instead of sugar and also a Lemon&Lime flavoured variant of the original recipe. The original Solo can was designed for DDB Needham Melbourne (Creative Director - Noel Schoelbridge) formally Hughes Satchwell by Les Mason Design (Simon Josephson Designer and Bill Quan Production).
Positioned as a highly masculine drink, Solo presents an overtly male image in its aggressive television commercials. The 'Solo man' character (acted by Michael Ace, PE Teacher)and slogans 'The thirst crusher' and 'Light on the fizz, so you can slam it down fast' were used in advertising until the early 1990s. The commercials often featured scenes of men taking part in activities such as athletics or extreme sports. Since becoming a sponsor of the Football Federation of Australia, the slogan 'Game On' has been used.
In 2012, the Solo man was revived by the advertising agency BMF as part of a new Solo advertising campaign
Cadbury Schweppes sold a similar citrus drink named Rondo in the United States market during the late 1970s and 80s. Like Solo, Rondo's marketing was positioned as a similarly masculine drink. Its aggressive commercials were parodied in the 2006 film Idiocracy as 'Brawndo: The Thirst Mutilator'.
Using the Australian Solo as an inspiration, Cadbury Schweppes has also sold an energy drink in the U.S. called Coolah Energy. It used the tagline 'Energy from Down Under'. It listed boronia as an ingredient, a citrus plant in Australia known more worldwide for use in floral arrangements than its fruit. Coolah Energy has since been discontinued.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solo_(Australian_soft_drink)

situations.text:
Enzymes are both proteins and biological catalysts (biocatalysts). Catalysts accelerate chemical reactions. The molecules upon which enzymes may act are called substrates, and the enzyme converts the substrates into different molecules known as products. Almost all metabolic processes in the cell need enzyme catalysis in order to occur at rates fast enough to sustain life. Metabolic pathways depend upon enzymes to catalyse individual steps. The study of enzymes is called enzymology and a new field of pseudo enzyme analysis has recently grown up, recognising that during evolution, some enzymes have lost the ability to carry out biological catalysis, which is often reflected in their amino acid sequences and unusual 'pseudo catalytic' properties.
Enzymes are known to catalyse more than 5,000 biochemical reaction types. Other biocatalysts are catalytic RNA molecules, called ribozymes. Enzymes' specificity comes from their unique three-dimensional structures.
Like all catalysts, enzymes increase the reaction rate by lowering its activation energy. Some enzymes can make their conversion of substrate to product occur many millions of times faster. An extreme example is orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase, which allows a reaction that would otherwise take millions of years to occur in milliseconds. Chemically, enzymes are like any catalyst and are not consumed in chemical reactions, nor do they alter the equilibrium of a reaction. Enzymes differ from most other catalysts by being much more specific. Enzyme activity can be affected by other molecules: inhibitors are molecules that decrease enzyme activity, and activators are molecules that increase activity. Many therapeutic drugs and poisons are enzyme inhibitors. An enzyme's activity decreases markedly outside its optimal temperature and pH, and many enzymes are (permanently) denatured when exposed to excessive heat, losing their structure and catalytic properties.
Some enzymes are used commercially, for example, in the synthesis of antibiotics. Some household products use enzymes to speed up chemical reactions: enzymes in biological washing powders break down protein, starch or fat stains on clothes, and enzymes in meat tenderizer break down proteins into smaller molecules, making the meat easier to chew.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enzyme

questions.text: Enzymes can be used to:
options: Make particles move faster so they react faster
Breakdown product particles so reactions occur faster
Lower the time it takes for a reaction to occur
questions.explanation: In the 1st paragraph, it states that “catalysts accelerate chemical reactions”, and that “enzymes are both proteins and biological catalysts”. Therefore, it can be inferred that enzymes increase the speed at which chemical reactions go; ie. lowering the time for the reaction. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the activity of enzymes except:
options: They function optimally at a particular temperature and pH
Their specificity makes them similar to other catalysts
If a patient suffering from heart disease requires antibiotics, they are likely to have been synthesised through the use of enzymes
They can be affected by other molecules
questions.explanation: In the 3rd paragraph it states that “enzymes differ from most other catalysts by being much more specific” – therefore the answer is B.

questions.text: According to the passage, all of the following are uses of enzymes except:
options: Softening meat so it can be cooked faster
If a child spills yoghurt on his shirt, the enzyme containing washing powder can be used to remove the stain
questions.explanation: There is nothing in the passage to suggest option C, and the last part of the last paragraph says that enzymes break down meats so they are easier to chew, not softening it. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: Enzymology:
options: Has discovered unusual pseudo-catalytic properties in enzymes
Was responsible for the creation of the term ribozymes
Involves studying the action of proteins and biological catalysts
questions.explanation: In the 1st paragraph it is stated that enzymology is the study of enzymes, and we know from the first line that enzymes are proteins and biological catalysts. Therefore the answer is D.

situations.text:
Hadrian’s Wall is the remains of stone fortifications built by the Roman Empire following its conquest of Britain in the second century A.D. The original structure stretched more than 70 miles across the northern English countryside from the River Tyne near the city of Newcastle and the North Sea, west to the Irish Sea. Hadrian’s Wall included a number of forts as well as a ditch designed to protect against invading troops. The remnants of a stone wall are still visible in many places.
Contrary to popular belief, Hadrian’s Wall does not, nor has it ever, served as the border between England and Scotland, two of the four countries that make up the United Kingdom. However, it does hold significance as a UNESCO World Heritage site and a major tourist attraction.
Hadrian’s Wall is located near the border between modern-day Scotland and England. It runs in an east-west direction, from Wallsend and Newcastle on the River Tyne in the east, traveling about 73 miles west to Bowness-on-Solway on Solway Firth. The wall took at least six years to complete. Construction started at the east end and moved westward. The work was completed by Roman soldiers.
Historians believe the original plan was to build a wall of stone or turf, fronted by a wide, deep ditch. The wall would feature a guarded gate every mile, with two observation towers in between each gate. Ultimately, 14 forts were added to the wall, and were augmented by an “earthwork” known as the Vallum to the south. It is essentially a large mound designed to serve as another defensive bulwark. Hadrian’s Wall was named a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1987. It remains unguarded, meaning tourists visiting the site have unfettered access, despite concerns over damage. More recently, when London hosted the Summer Olympics in 2012, Hadrian’s Wall was part of an art installation called “Connecting Light.”
Source: https://www.history.com/topics/ancient-rome/hadrians-wall

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be true about Hadrian’s Wall?
options: Protective features of the Wall included several forts and a ditch at its rear
The Romanian empire constructed the wall to protect itself purely from British troops
The wall was a protective mechanism erected by the Romans as a form of defence
The wall was constructed in exactly 6 years
questions.explanation: The passage states in paragraph 1 that the wall was a fortification built by the Roman Empire – which implies that it was a form of defence. Therefore, the best answer is C.

questions.text: Regarding the current status of Hadrian’s Wall, which of the following is most likely to be true?
options: Hadrian’s Wall is no longer a UNESCO World Heritage site
The wall has never lined the border of modern-day Scotland and England
Due to concerns over damage, the site is partially restricted to tourists
The wall was featured in London during the Summer Olympics
questions.explanation: Paragraph 4 states that when London hosted the Summer Olympics in 2012, the wall was featured in an art installation called ‘Connecting Light’. Therefore the answer is D.

questions.text: All of the following are false about the original plan of the wall except:
options: The original plan to build Hadrian’s Wall featured both stone and turf
More than seventy guarded gates would line the wall
A wall was fronted by a long, narrow ditch
questions.explanation: Given that “the wall would feature a guarded gate every mile”, and we know that the original structure “stretched more than 70 miles”, it can be inferred that at least 70 guards would line the wall. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be false about Hadrian’s Wall?
options: It took seven years to build Hadrian’s Wall
The wall was constructed from its east end to its west end by slaves
Only parts of the wall are still remaining to be seen by tourists
The wall is located in the United Kingdom
questions.explanation: The passage states that “the work was completed by Roman soldiers”, therefore the answer is B, as slaves did not construct the wall.

situations.text:
Coronaviruses are a group of related viruses that cause diseases in mammals and birds. In humans, coronaviruses cause respiratory tract infections that can range from mild to lethal. Mild illnesses include some cases of the common cold (which has other possible causes, predominantly rhinoviruses), while more lethal varieties can cause SARS, MERS, and COVID-19. Symptoms in other species vary: in chickens, they cause an upper respiratory tract disease, while in cows and pigs they cause diarrhea. There are yet to be vaccines or antiviral drugs to prevent or treat human coronavirus infections.
Coronaviruses constitute the subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, in the family Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, and realm Riboviria. They are enveloped viruses with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome and a nucleocapsid of helical symmetry. The genome size of coronaviruses ranges from approximately 26 to 32 kilobases, one of the largest among RNA viruses. They have characteristic club-shaped spikes that project from their surface, which in electron micrographs create an image reminiscent of the solar corona from which their name derives.
Coronaviruses are large pleomorphic spherical particles with bulbous surface projections. The average diameter of the virus particles is around 120 nm (.12 μm). The diameter of the envelope is approximately 80 nm (.08 μm) and the spikesare approximately 20 nm (.02 μm) long. The virus in electron micrographs appears as a distinct pair of electron dense shells.
The viral envelope consists of a lipid bilayer where the membrane (M), envelope (E) and spike (S) structural proteins are anchored. A subset of coronaviruses (specifically the members of betacoronavirus subgroup A) also have a shorter spike-like surface protein called hemagglutinin esterase (HE).
Inside the envelope, there is the nucleocapsid, which is formed from multiple copies of the nucleocapsid (N) protein, which are bound to the positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome in a continuous beads-on-a-string type conformation. The lipid bilayer envelope, membrane proteins, and nucleocapsid protect the virus when it is outside the host cell.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus

questions.text: According to the passage, coronaviruses:
options: Are a group of disease causing viruses that impact only humans
Have not been observed to have an impact in animals
questions.explanation: The 3rd paragraph states that “coronaviruses are large pleomorphic spherical particles” – therefore the answer is D.

questions.text: Coronaviruses are composed of:
options: Projections into the inner shell of the viruses
questions.explanation: The final line of the passage states that “membrane proteins… protect the virus when it is outside the host call” – therefore it can be inferred that coronaviruses have protective membranous proteins. Therefore, the answer is C. The answer is not B because coronaviruses appears as electron dense shells, however that does not mean that they are composed of electron dense shells.

questions.text: In addition to spanning an average diameter of 120nm, coronaviruses as they are known currently:
options: Consist of a nuclear envelope spanning 80nm
Have spikes on their surface that are their form of weapon
Cannot cause upper respiratory tract disease in cows
Cannot be counteracted by antiviral medication
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “there are yet to be vaccines or antiviral drugs to prevent or treat human coronavirus infections”. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: Which of the following are true about the nucleocapsid of coronaviruses
options: It shelters the lipid bilayer envelope
It provides a form of resistance for the virus
It has the second largest diameter of all components of the virus
questions.explanation: The final paragraph states that the nucleocapsid protects the virus when it is outside the host cell, so it is implied that it provides some sort of resistance and protection for the virus. Therefore the best answer is B.

situations.text: Not all musicians are AMEB certified, but all musicians who are AMEB certified have excellent piano and violin playing skills. Some musicians who are AMEB certified know how to play the guitar.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: All musicians with excellent piano and violin playing skills are AMEB certified
Not all musicians who are AMEB certified know how to play the guitar
Some musicians who are not AMEB certified have excellent piano and violin playing skills
If a musician knows how to play the guitar, he must be AMEB certified
The musicians who play the piano and are AMEB certified also have excellent violin playing skills
questions.explanation:
1. All musicians who are AMEB certified have excellent piano and violin playing skills, however that does not mean that everyone who has an AMEB certification has excellent piano and violin skills. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Some = More than 1, less than All. Not All = Less than All. Therefore, according to the statement, there could be no musicians that play the guitar. However the question stem states that there are some, so at least one musician plays the guitar. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. This could be the case, but there is nothing in the stem to suggest that it must be or is the case. Therefore, as it falls under the ‘can’t tell’ category, as we cannot be certain, the answer is NO.
4. There is nothing to suggest that a musician must be AMEB certified to play the guitar. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. All musicians who are AMEB certified have excellent piano and violin playing anyway, so this musician must have excellent violin skills. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: Great Barrier Reef’s greatest coral bleaching event happened in 1997. The increase in carbon in the water led to 100,000km of corals bleached and the death of 7,000 fish.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The world’s worst coral bleaching event happened in 1997
Most fish died from a 1997 coral bleaching event
Coral bleaching should be prevented at all costs
If the carbon levels were to increase in the water again, more fish may die
There has not been a bigger coral bleaching event in the Great Barrier Reef since 1997
questions.explanation:
1. There is nothing to suggest that this event was the worst. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We do not know if 7,000 fish is most fish or not, as we do not know the overall fish population. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We do not have any information about this statement, so it would be an assumption. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. If the increase in carbon in the water led to the coral bleaching, then it is a possibility that more fish may die if it happens again. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow. (note: this says ‘may’, not ‘will’’)
5. As this event is the greatest coral bleaching event for the Great Barrier Reef, there has not been a bigger one since 1977. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: A mountain is a type of hill. All hills have slopes and valleys. Some valleys have dunes, but if there are no dunes in the valleys, then there will be waterfalls.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: A mountain has slopes and valleys
If a mountain does not have a dune, it will have a waterfall.
If something has a waterfall, it must be a mountain
Some valleys do not have dunes
questions.explanation:
1. A mountain is a hill and all hills have slopes and valleys, therefore a mountain will have slopes an valleys. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. A mountain has valleys, so if there are no dunes in the valleys then there will be waterfalls in these valleys in these mountains. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. All mountains are hills, but not all hills are mountains (mountains are a type of hill. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Although mountains may have waterfalls, just because something has a waterfall doesn’t mean it is a mountain (could be another type of hill). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. If some valleys have dunes, then at least 1 valley does not have a dune. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: All cats that meow loudly are black. Cat B meows loudly. Cat A is not black.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Cats that meow softly are not black
Cat A does not meow loudly
There may be some white cats that meow loudly
Cat B and Cat A are different colours
questions.explanation:
1. This is an assumption – we do not know anything about cats that meow softly. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. If Cat A meows loudly, it will be black. Since it is not black, it cannot meow loudly then. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Since all cats that meow loudly are black, and cat B meows loudly, it must be black. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. There is no information about white cats here. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. If Cat B meows loudly it must be black, and since Cat A is not black it must be another colour to Cat B. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: In a specific swimming pool, some male instructors are athletes, and no male instructors can run a marathon.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: There are female instructors at the swimming pool

2. Given that no male instructor can run a marathon, if the instructor could run a marathon they cannot be a male. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. We do not know anything about Tobias Swimming pool, and we do not know if this specific swimming pool is Tobias Swimming pool. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. There could be marathon runners that are instructors at the swimming pool, as they could be female, but we don’t know for sure, however we can’t say definitively that they are not. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. If some male instructors are athletes, then at least 1 male instructor is not an athlete. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: Gerard has some beans and some cans that he needs to sort. If he puts one bean into each of the cans he has, he has seven beans left over. However, if he puts two beans in each can instead, he is left with two beans.

questions.text: How many cans does he have?
questions.explanation: If we make 2 simultaneous equations, where b = beans and c = cans: (1) b = c + 7, (2) b = 2c + 2. If we solve for c by equating the two equations, so that c + 7 = 2c + 2, we get that c = 5. Alternatively, you could work through the answer options by subbing them into the question. Therefore the answer is A.

situations.text: Two dots move around an octagon along its corners. Dot 1 moves around the octagon 2 corners at a time clockwise, whereas Dot 2 moves around the octagon 3 corners at a time anti-clockwise. Both dots moves at the same time.

questions.text: Where should they be placed at the beginning if they are to meet at the same corner on their 3rd move?
options: Dot 1 at A, Dot 2 at H
Dot 1 at A, Dot 2 at G
Dot 1 at F, Dot 2 at C
Dot 1 at F, Dot 2 at B
questions.explanation: The easiest way to figure this problem out is to use the answer options and check if each one works. Note that if Dot 1 moves around 2 corners at a time, that means it essentially skips 1 spot, whereas Dot 2 skips 2 spots. Also remember that they are going opposite directions. Therefore the answer is A. If Dot 1 starts at A, it will end at G, and if Dot 2 starts at H, it will end at G as well.

situations.text:
A school has 3 sessions a day. On Monday, a total of 80 students attended at least 1 of the 3 sessions.
16 students attended only the first session.
16 students attended only the first and second session.
12 students attended only the third class.
No students attended both the first and third session.
18 students attended only the second and third session.

questions.text: How many students attended the second session altogether?
questions.explanation: You could draw a Venn diagram for this problem, but can be solved without one. Given we know 80 students attended, we can subtract 16 and 12 from 80 to give us 52 (essentially all the numbers that are not in the circle representing the 2nd session). Therefore the answer is D.

situations.text:
Four people gathered to buy one thing in a souvenir shop in Australia, each from four other countries, either America, India, China or New Zealand. There were only 3 types of souvenirs in the shop. Each item was purchased by at least one person.
The person from India bought a boomerang as a souvenir.
The Chinese person and American did not buy the same souvenir as anyone else.
The beer stubby was not bought by the New Zealander.

questions.text: Which of the following MUST be false?
options: The New Zealander bought a teacup
The Chinese person did not buy the beer stubby
The Indian bought the same thing as the New Zealander
Either the Chinese or American person bought the beer stubby
questions.explanation: Given that there are only 3 souvenir types in the shop, and the Indian already bought one type, and the Chinese and American must have different types to anyone else, the New Zealander has to have the same type as the Indian. Therefore he must have a boomerang, not a teacup. Therefore, the answer is A.

situations.text:
Nicole, Nikki, Neal and Nabi went to a theme park, and each went on 4 separate rides, either the roller coaster, the spin wheel, the maze and the giant swing. The four events cost $35, $45, $50 or $60 (not in order).
Nicole chose to ride the roller coaster and paid $15 less than Nabi.
Nabi hates spin wheels but did not pay the most for his ride.
Nikki went on either the giant swing or paid $50.

questions.text: If Neal spent more than Nikki on his ride, which ride cost $45?
questions.explanation: Given that Nikki went on either the giant swing or paid 50 dollars, we know that the giant swing is not $50. Since Neal spent more than Nikki on his ride, he cannot have paid $35 since it is the lowest. Nicole paid either 35 or 45 dollars since she paid 15 dollars less than Nabi. Therefore Nabi paid either 50 or 60 dollars and since he did not pay the most, he must have paid $50. Therefore Nikki went on the giant swing. If Neal spent more than Nikki on his ride, he would have had to pay $60 (since Nikki has to now pay $35 since Nabi is paying $50). Therefore the giant swing has to be $45 (only price remaining for Nikki). Therefore the answer is D.

situations.text: Would schools be a safer environment if harsher punishments were implemented for bullying?

options: Yes, students would learn better if they didn’t have to worry about bullying
Yes, a psychological study showed that the fear of punishment is a direct deterrent for most bullies
No, bullies would begin bullying more as an act of defiance against the rules
No, this could impede on the education of children deemed ‘bullies’
questions.explanation: Answer option B is the strongest because it refers to evidence and focuses on the relationship between punishment and reducing bullying – the other options do not deal with the problem of reducing bullying or use opinions and assumptions.

situations.text: Should shooting be removed from the Olympic Games?

options: Yes, it promotes violence to children
Yes, shooting events are the least popular in the games
No, it has a rich history in the games and is therefore an essential element
No, in the past 50 years, shooting events have generated more than 5% of the Olympics total revenue
questions.explanation: Answer option D is the strongest as it provides an evidence-based argument that is not based on opinion or assumptions like the other 3 options.

situations.text: Should scoring systems be removed from sport for children under 10?

options: Yes, if kids get too caught up in the scores from young ages, it would detract from the true value of sport
Yes, this would shift the dynamic towards good sportsmanship in later years
No, psychologists recommend competitive sport from early ages as a means of developing healthy coping mechanisms to deal with failure
No, sport is competitive by nature and this shouldn’t be changed
questions.explanation: Answer option C is the strongest because it is based on evidence and professional recommendations and deals with all the elements of the question (such as the young age of the children). Option A is not the strongest because although valid it is not based on evidence like Option C.

situations.text: Should there be a blanket ban on contact sports?

options: Yes, without contact sports there would be far less traumatic brain injuries
Yes, there is no good way to mitigate the risk of contact sports without getting rid of them completely
No, this is an infringement on freedom
No, it has been shown that with proper protective gear and strict adherence to the rules, the risk posed by contact sports can be minimised
questions.explanation: Answer option D is the strongest because it is based on evidence and provides logical reasoning, whereas the other arguments rely on more emotional arguments. Option B is not the strongest because is does not rely on evidence like option D, albeit not a totally incorrect response.

situations.text:
Dementia is a syndrome – usually of a chronic or progressive nature – in which there is deterioration in cognitive function (i.e. the ability to process thought) beyond what might be expected from normal ageing. It affects memory, thinking, orientation, comprehension, calculation, learning capacity, language, and judgement. Consciousness is not affected. The impairment in cognitive function is commonly accompanied, and occasionally preceded, by deterioration in emotional control, social behaviour, or motivation. Dementia results from a variety of diseases and injuries that primarily or secondarily affect the brain, such as Alzheimer's disease or stroke.
Source: https://www.who.int/

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Dementia mostly affects people who are old
People with the onset of dementia may experience unstable emotions
Someone with Alzheimer’s disease will have dementia
If someone gets hit in the head, they could possibly get dementia
A person with dementia will never lose consciousness
questions.explanation:
1. Although dementia is linked to age in the passage, we don’t know who is mostly affected by it. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. The passage states “the impairment in cognitive function is commonly accompanied… by deterioration in emotional control” – unstable emotions can be inferred from a lack of emotional control. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Dementia results from Alzheimer’s yes, however the passages does not state that it is a certainty, as dementia “results from a variety of diseases”. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. The passage states that dementia can result from injuries to the brain, Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Although consciousness is not affected we don’t know if a person with dementia will NEVER lose consciousness/ Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
Company Electrobill has conducted a survey of the Watt household and has measured their energy usage per month over two years.
Source: https://support.goldensoftware.com/hc/en-us/articles/115005366867-Creating-and-Using-Bar-Charts-in-Grapher

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.

questions.explanation:

2. On observation, the dark blue representing 2008 is greater than the lighter blue representing 2009. It is close to around 200 kilowatt-hours/month higher. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:

She records the number of times she does either of these activities for a week in March for every year from 2014 to 2017. Her chart is seen below. Dark blue = sneezing. Medium blue = coughing. Light blue = scratching her hair.
Source: https://google.github.io/charts/flutter/example/bar_charts/grouped.html

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Emily’s sneezing 100 times in a week in 2016 is the result of a sandstorm that triggered her allergic response.
In 2015, on average, Emily may have coughed 7 times a day.
Emily’s total sneezing in the data collected in 2014, 2015 and 2017 is equal to her total sneezing in the data collected for 2016.

Emily’s number of coughs in the one week in 2016 is approximately 10% of her number of sneezes in one week in 2016.

3. The sneezing data collected in 2014, 15 and 17 is more than that collected in 2016. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We don’t know this for sure so this would be an extrapolation and assumption beyond the graph. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. 10/100 = 10%. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

More than half voted for A
B was the least popular brand

options: Both computers and phones only have touch screens
Only some computers have touch screens

situations.text: Thirty-five students in a class shared the contents of their lunchboxes with the rest of the class. Twenty students had both fruits and vegetables in their lunchboxes. However, 14 students did not have fruits in their lunchbox and 11 students had vegetables only in their lunchbox.

questions.text: How many students did not have vegetables nor fruits in their lunchbox?
questions.explanation: If 20 students had both types in their lunchbox, then 15 did not have both (one type or none). If 14 students did not have fruits and 11 had vegetables only, therefore 3 did not have either (and 1 had fruits only). Therefore, the answer is A.

situations.text: In a school nurse’s notes she has a list of 47 students’ health records. The only allergies that students can have are to eggs and peanuts. A total of 20 students had an allergy to only one thing, but there is 1 more student with allergies to both things than those students with no allergies. How many students are not allergic to both eggs and peanuts?

questions.explanation: If 20 students had an allergy to one thing, then 27 had an allergy to both or none. If 1 more had an allergy to both than none, then we can deduce that 13 had an allergy to none and 14 had an allergy to both. Therefore the number of students who are not allergic to both (so one + none) = 20 + 13 = 33. Therefore, the answer is D.

situations.text: A survey of 160 university students and the emotions they had experienced over the last week were recorded.

questions.text: What does the letter D represent?
options: University students who had experienced anxiety and frustration
University students who had experienced excitement and frustration
University students who had experienced happiness and frustration
University students who had experienced excitement and anxiety
questions.explanation: D sits in the circle and square intersection, which is the intersection between happiness and frustration. Therefore, the answer is C.

situations.text: A netball coach has to choose between Gina and Michaela to be selected for their netball team. Michaela makes 63% of shots that she takes and shoots an average of 5 times per game. Gina misses 0.37 of shots she takes and shoots an average of 6 times per game. Who should the coach choose?

options: Gina, because she has a higher shooting accuracy.
Gina, because she is likely to score more points for the team than Michaela
Michaela, because is she the more accurate player.
Michaela, because she has a 22% chance of making all 5 shots
questions.explanation: They both have the same accuracy ( as 1 – 0.37 = 0.63 or 63% for Gina), however Gina shoots an average of 1 more time than Michaela. Therefore, the answer is B.

situations.text: Malone’s fabric company can buy printers from Company A or Company B. Maintenance of both company’s printers costs $150. Company A’s printer costs $210, but the probability that it will require maintenance is 0.82. Company B’s printer costs $190 and will not require maintenance 18% of the time. Which company should Malone buy the printer from?

options: Company A, because it is $20 cheaper
Company B, because it is $20 cheaper
Company A, because it has a higher chance of needing maintenance
Company B, because it’s maintenance would cost less.
questions.explanation: Both company printers require maintenance 82% of the time, however company B’s printer costs $20 less than that of company A. Therefore, the answer is B.

situations.text: Peter has a bag of marbles that he is playing with, that has 5 green marbles, 6 blue marbles and 7 red marbles. If he picks out 2 red marbles on the first try, what is the probability that he will pick out a green marble on his second try?

questions.explanation: There are 18 marbles to start with, but if 2 red marbles are removed on the first try, there remains only 16. Since the number of green marbles hasn’t changed, the probability of getting a green marble on the second try is 5/16 (not 5/18 because 2 red ones have been removed already). Therefore, the answer is B.

situations.text: On Monday there is a 30% chance of rain. If it rains on one day, there is a 70% chance it rains again the next day. If it does not rain one day, there is a 4 in 5 chance that it rains the next day. What is the chance that it rains on Tuesday?

questions.explanation: We have to calculate to options here and add them together. Let’s say R = rain and R’ = no rain. We need to calculate RR and R’R (that is, rain Monday rain Tuesday, and no rain Monday rain Tuesday). Therefore, since RR = 0.3*0.7 = 0.21, and R’R = 0.7*0.8 = 0.56, adding these two together gives us a total probability of 0.21 + 0.56 = 0.77. Therefore, the answer is C.

situations.text: Orin and Pippin are in an egg carrying competition, where each competitor has to carry an egg in a spoon without it falling for 10 metres. The chance that Orin drops his egg is 1/15. The chance that Pippin drops his egg is 3 times Orin’s chance. What is the probability that both of them drop their eggs?

questions.explanation: The chance of Pippin dropping his eggs is 3 * 1/15 = 3/15 = 1/5. The chance that both of them drop it is equal to 1/15 * 1/5 = 1/75 (15*5 = 75, therefore you know it is 1/75 as 1*1=1). Therefore, the answer is A.

situations.text: The diagram below represents a mega chocolate that is being sold in a store. The store would like to redesign the chocolate in certain ways so is considering some adjustments.

questions.text: If someone were to eat half this chocolate bar, how much chocolate would they be consuming?
questions.explanation: To calculate the area of the trapezium you can break it up into a rectangle and 2 triangles (essentially another rectangle): so (45 * 20) + (7.5 * 20) = 1,050. Now to find the volume, we could multiply 1,050 by 80, but since we are only finding half the volume, we only need to multiply by 40. Therefore 1,050 * 40= 42,000 cm^3. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: Regulators say that the chocolate bar can only have 84cm^3 of chocolate in it for health reasons. If they wanted to maintain the same ratio of dimensions, how long would the adjusted chocolate be?
questions.explanation: Given that the full volume is 84,000cm^3 (42,000 * 2 as found in the working for Q1), we need to reduce the volume by 1,000 times. Since we are dealing with volume, each dimension needs to be reduced by the same amount to maintain the ratio of dimensions, each side needs to be reduced by 10 (since 103 = 1,000). Thus, 80/10 = 8cm. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: If the store wanted to add a triangular prism to the top of this shape, for a total height of 40cm, how much chocolate would they need to add to the top of this shape?
questions.explanation: To calculate the volume of the triangular prism needed for the top: we know the base is 45cm. For a height of total 40cm, the height of this new prism is 20cm. The length is the same as the bottom part at 80cm. Therefore the volume of this prism is (0.5*45*20) * 80 = 36,000cm^3 (this is the area of the triangle multiplied by the length). Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: If they wanted to wrap this chocolate, how much wrapping would they need (assume the length of the trapezium diagonal side is 50cm)?
questions.explanation: We need to find the surface area. Surface area = trapezium area*2 + bottom rectangle + diagonal rectangles*2 + top rectangle. Thus, surface area = 1,050*2 + 60*80 + 50*80*2 + 45*80 = 18,500cm^2. Therefore, the answer is D.

situations.text: The following label shows the nutritional information of a packet of nutripowder. The nutritional information shown is per serving. DV = daily recommended intake for an average person

questions.text: How much fat and carbs is an average person recommended to consume in a day?
questions.explanation: If 12% of fat + carbs each makes up the DV, then 0.12*x = 8 for fat and 0.12*x = 0.37 for carbs, where x is total daily intake (DV). Therefore x for fat = 66.666… and x for carbs = 308.333…, so adding them together gets 375g, which is answer D.

questions.text: If the nutripowder only contains the elements shown in the table, how much iron is present in the nutripowder, to the closest value below?
questions.explanation: If 2/3 cup is 55g, then the total amount of remaining components after removing the components with weights in them is 6.84g (55 – 8 – 0.16 – 37 – 3). Therefore 0.45*6.84 = 3.078g = 3g. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: How many calories are in this packet of nutripowder?
questions.explanation: If there are 230 calories per serving, and there are 8 servings, then 230*8=1,840 calories in the packet. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: How many cups of nutripowder would someone need to get 9 grams of protein?
questions.explanation: You would need 3 servings (as protein is 3g a serving), and since each serving is 2/3 cup, that is a total of 2 cups. Therefore, the answer is B.

situations.text: The table below shows the percentage of sales for different products at the National Forecourt Store across 3 years, forecasting sales for 2020. In 2015 they made $10 million. Every item in the table costs the same per item, except for fuel which raised $5 million in sales in 2015.

questions.text: If 800,000 newspapers and magazines were sold in 2015, how much would it have cost to buy 2 newspapers in 2015 from this store?
questions.explanation: In 2015, they made 0.16*10 million = $1.6 million from newspapers and magazines. Thus, the unit/cost for this would be $2/newspaper or magazine, since there are 800,000 units sold in 2015, and so 2 units would cost $4. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: If the store made 25% more in 2015 than 2010, how much did they make from fuel in 2010?
questions.explanation: Fuel revenue for 2010 = 5 million/1.25 = $4 million (as 1.25*fuel revenue in 2010 = 5 million, the fuel revenue in 2015). Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: If the store made 15 million dollars in 2010, how much more money did they make from food/groceries in 2010 than 2015?
questions.explanation:
0.21*15 million = $3.15 million in 2010. 0.10*10 million = $1 million.
3.15 – 1 = $2.15 million. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: If it is expected that car spares will generate sales of $570,000 for the store, how much are they expecting to earn in 2020 overall?
questions.explanation: If 0.02*x = 570,000, with x = total revenue in 2020, then x = 570,000/0.02 = $28.5 million. Therefore, the answer is D.

situations.text: The following line graph shows the number of 3 different plants a nursery had in stock in 2017. In 2016 there were a total of 200 plants in stock, including other plants.

questions.text: What was the average rate of increase in numbers per month of roses from February to April?
questions.explanation: February-March increase = 5 roses. March-April increase = 2 roses. Therefore the average rate of increase = (5+2)/2 = 3.5 roses/month. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: What was the difference in the percentage increase between the number of Tulips from January to May to Orchids, to the nearest percent?
questions.explanation: January-May % increase for Tulips = 10/10 * 100 = 100%. January-May % increase for Orchids = 10/15 * 100 = 66.67%. Therefore the difference in percentage increase is approximately 33%. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: If in February 2017 there were 200 plants in stock in the nursery, what percentage of the total stock in February did the 3 plants compose?
questions.explanation: (15+15+15)/200 = 22.5%. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: If the orchids composed 10% of the total stock in May 2017, by what percentage did the total plant stock in the nursery change from 2016 to 2017?
questions.explanation: If 0.10*x = 25, where x is the total amount of plants in may 2017, then x = 250. Therefore the percentage increase from 200 in 2016 to 250 in May 2017 is 25%. (50/200 = 0.25). Therefore, the answer is B.

situations.text: The following table shows the annual taxable income of different financial brackets and their respective tax rates.

questions.text: If Samantha earned a taxable income 20,500, how much tax would she have to pay?
questions.explanation: 0.21 * 20,500 = $4,305. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: How much more tax would someone who earns a taxable income of $30,000 pay compared to someone who earns a taxable income $10,000?
If the amount of taxes gained from the first bracket (0-8,900) amounted to $15,700, what was the average taxable income for the 26 people who contributed that tax?
questions.explanation: If 0.10*x = 15,700, where x = total income of everyone in that tax bracket, then x = 15,700/0.1 = $157,000. Therefore the average income is 157,000/26 = $6,038.46. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: If 25% of John’s income of 450,000 is taxable, how much did he pay on taxes?
questions.explanation: 0.25 * 450,000 = $112,500 in taxable income. Therefore, he falls into the 4th bracket, paying 35% tax. 0.35*112,500 = $39,500. Therefore, the answer is D.

situations.text: Here is some information about the costs of leasing land in Country Y. The table shows the costs in thousands of dollars per hectare to lease the land. In addition, one must pay 8,000 dollars as a one-time fee for the land itself.

questions.text: How much would it cost to lease a piece of land for public use for 5 years?
questions.explanation: Falls into 3+ category, so 750 + 8,000 (one time fee) = $8,750. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: There was an error in the calculation of the lease for Mixed Use for 2 years. If the current price is 40% lower than the actual price, what is the average leasing price for 2 years for all the 4 types of uses?
questions.explanation: Actual price for mixed use for 2 years = 400/0.40 = 1,000. Therefore the average is (180+360+500+1000)/4 = $510. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: Which of the following options is cheaper?
options: Leasing land for public use for a year and land for mixed use for 2 years
Leasing land for mixed use for a year and land for public use for 2 years
Leasing land for residential use for 3 years
Leasing land for business for 3 years and land for mixed use for 1 year

questions.text: If they were to introduce a new price for 4+ years and instead change the 3+ years options to only 3 years, how should they price the 4+ years option for business use if they followed the rate of price increase per year?
questions.explanation: The rate of increase each year for Business use is $90/year. Therefore for 4+ years it should be $360. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: An empty container is being filled with water at the rate of 5 litres every 45 seconds and leaks water at the rate of one litre every 180 seconds. What is the quantity of water in the container after one hour?
questions.explanation: After 1 hour the tank should be filled with 400L (since you have 5L*80). However the amount of water leaked after 1 hour is 20L (since you have 1L*20). Therefore there is actually 380L. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: A 20L rain tank has a leak in it. The hole in the tank means that rainwater can leak out at a rate of 200mL per hour. If at the end of Tuesday the tank is 3 quarters full, on what day would the tank run out of water?
questions.explanation: The amount of water at the end of Tuesday in the tank is 0.75*20 = 15L. The tank will run out of water after 75 hours (15,000/200 = 75 hours). At the end of Friday, the tank will still have 3L left (75 – 24*3 = 3). Therefore, the answer is D, for Saturday.

situations.text: A factory outputs 10 cartons of milk every 5 minutes. However, 1 carton of milk in every 20 is broken and cannot be exported.

questions.text: How many cartons can be exported in half an hour?
questions.explanation: After 30 minutes, 60 cartons are produced. However 3 cartons are broken (1/20 * 60), so only 57 can be exported. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: A new detection machine picks up cracks and enables workers to fix them before it’s too late, reducing the proportion of broken cartons to 1 in every 25. How many broken cartons will be produced in a 24-hr day?
questions.explanation: In 24hrs, 2,880 cartons are produced. Thus, 1/25 * 2,880 = 115.20 cartons. Since you cannot have 0.20 cartons, you have to round down as you cannot create 0.80 of a broken carton either. Therefore, the answer is B.

situations.text: The following graph shows the number of different types of vehicles produced in Global City in January

questions.text: What is the average of the top 4 most produced vehicle types?
questions.explanation: Top 4 most produced vehicles are full-size vans, luxury sedans, SUVs and station wagons. Therefore (15,000+18,000+10,000+12,000)/4 = 13,750 cars. Therefore, the answer is B. TIP: Don’t type in 15,000 in full, you can just type in 15 instead to save time and get 13.75 instead.

questions.text: What is the average number of vans made in January?
questions.explanation: (15,000+7,000)/2 = 11,000. (Full-size and minivans). Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: What is the proportion of vehicle types for which less than 6000 vehicles were produced in January?
questions.explanation: There were 8 types out of 14 that had under 6,000 vehicles produced. This can be simplified to 4/7. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: What is the closest median of the number of cars made in January for the above vehicle types?
questions.explanation: If the vehicles are arranged in ascending order of numbers, the median number of cars is close to 3,000 for an average of pickup trucks and large-sized sedans. Since there are 14 vehicles in total, the median will be an average of the middle to (so the 7th and 8th lowest). Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: What was the difference in male population in 1985 compared to 2010
questions.explanation: 152 – 116 = 36. Note the scale is in millions, so 36 million. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: What is the expected US male population in 2020
questions.explanation: 1.037*152 = 157.624, therefore in millions, 157,624,000. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: What is the expected total US population in 2020
questions.explanation: (1.037*152) + (0.874*151) = 289.598, therefore in millions, 289,598,000. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: What was the percentage difference between the increase in male population and the increase in female population from 1985 to 2010
questions.explanation: Males: (152-116)/116 = 31.03…%. Females: (157-122)/122 = 28.688…%. Therefore the male increase is approximately 2.34% greater than the female increase. Therefore, the answer is D.
