situations.text: A medical student, Jack, is complaining to his friend, James, about his mark in the recent clinical skills exam. He received a low mark and negative feedback despite believing that he performed well. How appropriate are each of the following responses by James in this situation?

questions.text: Read & Mark all the actions
actions: Complete the tasks without expressing her concerns to the supervisor
Ask about other tasks (that are clinically related) that Lauren could undertake
Ask advice from her tutor/academic adviser
Complain directly to the faculty about the supervisor
answer: Complain directly to the faculty about the supervisor
Ask about other tasks (that are clinically related) that Lauren could undertake
Complete the tasks without expressing her concerns to the supervisor
Ask advice from her tutor/academic adviser
questions.explanation: This response offers no direct solution to Lauren’s concerns and displays a lack of willingness to communicate. It is not awful as it is not confrontational in manner and no immediately negative consequences will come about.

questions.text: Tell Jack that results will balance out over time
questions.explanation: While this may seem appropriate on the surface, negative feedback will not necessarily be balanced by positive feedback unless the student takes proactive steps towards improvement.  Jack should seek to accept this feedback and change his practice for the better.

questions.text: Recommend that Jack complains to the faculty, even though he has no supporting evidence
questions.explanation: Students should not question or undermine the fairness of the marking process just because they received poor feedback – especially without evidence

questions.text: Encourage Jack to take some time to review his feedback and objectively analyse it
questions.explanation: Jack may be heated from the shock of receiving a less than expected mark and he should take some time to let it sink in and review his feedback

questions.text: Tell Jack that negative feedback is part of the process and that feedback should never be questioned
questions.explanation: While negative feedback is indeed part of the learning process, it isn’t that feedback should never be questioned. If there is evidence to suggest unfair marking or an error in the marking process, it should be looked into

situations.text: A patient, Jeffrey has an operation booked for tomorrow morning. His doctor, Dr Shauna, realises that she forgot to complete a final assessment of Jeffrey to ensure he is fit for surgery. This assessment is necessitated by the hospital. Dr Shauna won’t be able to see Jeffrey before his operation. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Shauna in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the team to switch Jeffrey’s surgery to later in the day tomorrow
questions.explanation: This solution acknowledges that the surgery requires the assessment to be carried out first and seeks to minimise the inconvenience to Jeffrey

questions.text: Immediately contact and explain the mistake to the surgical team
questions.explanation: It is important for doctors to admit their mistakes and informing the team will involve them in the decision-making process as a matter of urgency

questions.text: Pretend that the assessment was conducted and use the results of the patient’s previous assessment
questions.explanation: It is absolutely unacceptable for a doctor to fabricate patient results and, if there were associated complications with the surgery, the doctor could be held accountable

questions.text: Call the surgical team in the morning before Jeffrey’s appointment
questions.explanation: While acknowledging that the surgical team would have to be contacted and the surgery cannot be conducted without the assessment, Dr Shauna should seek to do this as a matter of urgency as there may not be enough time to rectify the situation in the morning before the operation

questions.text: Book in Jeffrey the morning before his operation and tell him to arrive early
questions.explanation: While acknowledging that the surgery cannot be conducted without the assessment, booking Jeffrey in without asking for his thoughts is not an appropriate course of action

situations.text: Makram and Raj are medical students at a GP clinic. They have to complete a lot of administerial worth with the receptionists and practice manager. At the end of one day, Raj complains loudly about the reception staff and practice manager and says that he shouldn’t have to do all this boring work. The patients in the waiting room and the receptionist appears to have heard this. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Makram in this situation?

questions.text: Advise that Raj justifies his opinion in front of the patients
questions.explanation: Raj should not discuss his opinion on this matter in front of the patients whatsoever

questions.text: Apologise to the receptionists on Raj’s behalf
questions.explanation: While it is good to acknowledge that Raj’s comments may have offended the receptionists, it is advisable for Raj instead to be encouraged to apologise

questions.text: Immediately tell Raj that his comments are inappropriate
questions.explanation: Whilst doing so will perhaps help Raj to understand that his comments aren’t appropriate, this should be done privately – to maintain professionalism and prevent a conflict

questions.text: Suggest that Raj vocalises his concerns to the academic coordinator
questions.explanation: Raj has the right to express his concerns but should be advised to do so privately, to the relevant members of staff (not in front of the reception staff)

questions.text: Express your agreement with Raj
questions.explanation: This will only serve to compound the situation and reinforce Raj’s abrasive comments – in front of the reception staff

situations.text: At a hospital ward, a medical student, Jennifer, sees a patient ambling aimlessly. He looks confused and every so often looks at the signage. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Jennifer in this situation?

questions.text: Give the patient directions to the administration desk
questions.explanation: While the patient may be lost and need to directions to the admin desk, it is not right to assume this – Jennifer should first clarify with the patient

questions.text: Read out the hospital signage to the patient
questions.explanation: While not awful, it is incorrect to assume that the patient is lost and cannot read the signage. Jennifer should first ask whether they are actually lost and provide a more helpful solution

questions.text: Take the patient to see the doctor as they may be unwell
questions.explanation: It is highly inappropriate to assume that this is the case and the doctor may be tending to other patients at the time

questions.text: Point out the patient to the reception staff and return to work
questions.explanation: While ensuring that the staff are made aware of this patient, it is not the receptionist’s responsibility to help the patient nor is there a guarantee that they will do so

questions.text: Ask the patient if they are lost or require any assistance
questions.explanation: This is the first thing that Jennifer should do to ensure that the patient receives the help that they need

situations.text: A medical student, Barbara, is at a hospital ward and overhears two doctors talking audibly about a patient’s details in the waiting room. The patients sitting in the waiting room appear to be uncomfortable and disturbed by this. A patient goes up to Barbara and complains. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Barbara in this situation?

questions.text: I will pass on your concerns to my supervisor right away
questions.explanation: Doing this will validate the patients concerns and ensure that the relevant members of staff are notified in a timely fashion

questions.text: Go up to the doctors and berate them for talking about patient details in this manner
questions.explanation: This would be a very inappropriate thing to do as it will create a scene in front of patients and publicly diminish their trust in the doctors

questions.text: Apologise to the patient and assure them that the situation will be dealt with promptly
questions.explanation: This will validate the patient’s concerns and provide them with reassurance that the situation will be dealt with

questions.text: Take the doctors aside and privately inform them that they may be overheard by patients
questions.explanation: This response is very appropriate as it functions to rectify the breach in confidentiality and does so in a polite manner

questions.text: Inform the doctors what you think the likely diagnosis of the patient is – to impress them
questions.explanation: Barbara should rectify the breach in confidentiality, not add to the discussion

situations.text: Linda and David are attending a university tutorial. David asks Linda a question quietly, to clarify the content, and the lecturer scolds him for talking in class. He then asks David to leave the tutorial as this is not a place for talking about unrelated matters. David doesn’t mention that he asked Linda a question about the content. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Linda in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the tutor to allow David to stay as his question was about the content
questions.explanation: Whilst this elucidates context to the tutor, David’s behaviour is still potentially distracting for the other students and the tutor

questions.text: Say nothing
questions.explanation: Linda should not intervene during the lecture, as to not disturb the class, however afterwards it would be preferable to explain the nature of David’s question to the tutor

questions.text: After the lesson, advise that David apologises for interrupting the tutor and also explains the nature of his question
questions.explanation: It is very appropriate for David to explain his actions to the tutor and apologise if he belives he may have interrupted the class

questions.text: Advise David to raise his hand and ask questions to the tutor instead in the future
questions.explanation: This will help prevent similar situations occurring in the future

questions.text: Immediately challenge the tutor for sending David out
questions.explanation: Linda should not be confrontational whatsoever in her manner and doing so will only anger the tutor and escalate the situation

situations.text: Jessica is a medical student. In the dissection hall, Martin sees her poking the eyeballs and being generally disrespectful to her cadaver. The tutor doesn’t appear to have noticed Jessica’s behaviour and Martin finds it disgusting and offensive. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Martin in this situation?

questions.text: Quietly ask Jessica not to do that
questions.explanation: By asking Jessica to refrain from such behaviour, Martin may encourage her to stop disrespecting the cadaver and by approaching the matter quietly he will strive to avoid confrontation

questions.text: Complain to the tutor
questions.explanation: While this may ultimately help Jessica refrain from such behaviour, Martin should ideally first strive to resolve the situation with Jessica

questions.text: Not say anything and continue to treat his cadaver with due respect
questions.explanation: While he should strive to set a good example for other students, Martin should also vocalise his concerns to Jessica if he is uncomfortable with her behaviour

questions.text: Berate Jessica for her actions
questions.explanation: It is highly inappropriate to escalate the situation in that manner and doing so will only cause conflict

questions.text: Attempt to remove the cadaver from Jessica’s table
questions.explanation: It is not Martin’s place to remove the cadaver and doing so would be highly inappropriate. He should instead seek to talk to Jessica and vocalise his concerns

situations.text: Adam is a medical student working at a GP clinic. A patient, Janice enters the GPs room complaining of shoulder pain. The GP has to rush out to attend a call and asks Adam to conduct a shoulder exam on Janice. While he knows that he has capable of conducting the exam and medical students are allowed to, Janice tells Adam that she doesn’t think he is qualified to do so. All the other doctors are busy. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Adam in this situation? Assume that each of the following responses would be said politely.

questions.text: I am familiar with this exam and there is nothing to worry about
questions.explanation: While this may help allay Janice’s fears, it would be best for Adam to strive to explore her concerns further

questions.text: Should I ask another doctor to complete the exam
questions.explanation: While recognising her concerns, as the other doctors are busy, this will take a long time and is based on one comment alone

questions.text: Could you explain why specifically you are concerned
questions.explanation: It is completely appropriate for David to ask for clarification about Janice’s concerns so that he can resolve them

questions.text: The doctor asked me to complete the exam, so I have to
questions.explanation: This response is highly inappropriate as it is completely dismissive of Janice’s concerns

questions.text: All the other doctors are busy at the moment, so if you’d like another doctor to complete the exam this may take a while
questions.explanation: While appropriate, Adam should first seek to explore Janice’s concerns further before jumping to the assumption that Janice does not want to be examined by a medical student

situations.text: A GP is required to vaccinate a young child, however, when the boy sees the needle he starts kicking and screaming that he wants to go home. How appropriate are each of the following responses by the GP in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the boy's mother to try to calm the boy down and then proceed
questions.explanation: While the mother may help on calming down the boy, it may be necessary to reschedule the appointment if he can’t be consoled

questions.text: Stop the consult and talk to the boy to try and put him at ease
questions.explanation: Stopping the consult is appropriate and talking to the boy may help ascertain why he is so fearful. It will additionally help build trust

questions.text: Sternly tell the boy to stop crying
questions.explanation: This will only add to the boy’s discomfort and may result in him crying even more

questions.text: Quickly inject the boy when he is distracted
questions.explanation: This will only degrade the boy’s trust in the doctor and may also upset the mother

questions.text: Tell the mother to reschedule the appointment
questions.explanation: While the appointment may need to be reschedule if the boy can’t be consoled, the doctor should seek to first put the boy at ease and attempt to calm him down – rescheduling should be a last resort

situations.text: A medical student is running late to a tutorial at a hospital when he sees an elderly couple ambling around the ward. They appear confused and lost. How appropriate are each of the following responses by the student in this situation?

questions.text: Direct the couple to the reception desk and rush off to the tutorial
questions.explanation: This is based on the assumption that the couple is indeed lost – when this might not be the case. The student should first clarify with the couple

questions.text: Talk to the couple and ask whether they are lost
questions.explanation: It is highly appropriate to talk to the couple and clarify whether they are indeed lost

questions.text: Ask another passing medical student, on their break, to tend to the couple
questions.explanation: While this may be helpful in guiding the couple, the student should ideally not delegate this to another student - as there is no guarantee that the other student will help out the couple

questions.text: Do not stop to help out the couple
questions.explanation: The medical student has the obligation to help the couple and, even if he is running late to the tutorial, he should do so

questions.text: Message the tutor that he will be late and help the couple
questions.explanation: This is highly appropriate as the student will not only be ensuring that the tutor knows that he will be late, they will also be helping the couple

situations.text: At the hospital café, which is used by both doctors and patients, a medical student overhears a doctor, who the student recognises, and a colleague discussing the recent results of a patient’s test. How appropriate are each of the following responses by the student in this situation?

questions.text: Privately tell the doctors that others in the café may hear these confidential results
questions.explanation: This will help close the breach in confidentiality and is done privately place in order to maintain public confidence

questions.text: In the café, audibly tell the doctors not to talk about patient results
questions.explanation: While this may help reassure patients that confidentiality breaches are not tolerated in the hospital

questions.text: Observe the same doctor in other situations to see if she repeatedly discusses patient results publicly
questions.explanation: While helping to determine whether this a repeated pattern of behaviour, the primary goal should be to immediately act to prevent this confidentiality breach

questions.text: Berate the doctors for discussing patient results publicly
questions.explanation: It is highly inappropriate for the student to deal with this situation in a confrontational manner and may result in its unnecessary escalation

questions.text: Ask a nearby patient at the café whether they would be comfortable with their results being discussed in public
questions.explanation: This is highly inappropriate and will only serve to further degrade public confidence in these doctors

situations.text: A team of medical students (along with their supervising doctor) are in charge of the care of a patient, Mr Smith. The supervisor notices that one student, Jeffrey, is not as involved as the others in providing care to this patient and often turns up late or inadequately prepared. How appropriate are each of the following responses by the supervisor in this situation?

questions.text: Ask Jeffrey why he comes late and inadequately prepared
questions.explanation: This would help alert Jeffrey to the fact that his behaviour has been observed and will help the supervisor investigate the reasons behind Jeffrey’s behaviour

questions.text: Inform Jeffrey that he will have to give him a poor review
questions.explanation: This may stress Jeffrey and erode the relationship with him. Instead, Jeffrey should be first warned and asked whether he needs support

questions.text: Ask Jeffrey how he is coping
questions.explanation: It is highly appropriate to further investigate Jeffrey’s situation and also demonstrates a degree of empathy

questions.text: Redistribute Jeffrey’s work to the other students to help him out
questions.explanation: This is highly appropriate and may overburden other students while stopping Jeffrey from getting adequate exposure

questions.text: Encourage Jeffrey to be on time and proactive in his role
questions.explanation: It is advisable for the supervisor to strive to motivate Jeffrey and doing so also demonstrates a degree of empathy

situations.text: At a local GP clinic, a young boy is brought in with a cut on his chin. Dr Raj suggests that the boy will need stitched, but the mother is concerned about the hygiene standards in the clinic. She says that she heard from another patient that the clinic and its instruments aren’t cleaned thoroughly. Dr Raj knows this isn’t the case. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Dr Raj in this situation?

questions.text: Reassure the mother that hygiene is the utmost priority at the clinic
questions.explanation: It is important to remind the patient that hygiene is prioritised – to help allay their concerns

questions.text: Offer to provide more information about the hygiene practices
questions.explanation: This will provide further reassurance to the mother and provide concrete evidence supporting the clinic’s focus on hygiene

questions.text: Disparage the mother’s concern due to its lack of evidence
questions.explanation: The mother’s concerns should be heard, acknowledged and addressed – not merely disparaged

questions.text: Ask what she heard from the other patient and why she/the other patient are not clinic’s hygiene
questions.explanation: It is definitely appropriate for Dr Raj to explore the mother’s concerns further and gain more context about the issue

questions.text: Clean the instruments again to put the patient at ease
questions.explanation: While this gesture may provide further reassurance to the mother, it is not necessary if the instruments have already been cleaned (this may be a waste of resources) and does not address the mother’s overarching concerns
